title: Air NZ boss trumpets record result
text:
Wed, Aug 26, 2015, 6:02 PM NZST - New Zealand Markets closed Air NZ boss trumpets record result AAP – 17 minutes ago Print 
Air New Zealand chief executive Christopher Luxon says the national carrier's record result stacks up against any airline in the world. 
Net profit rose to $NZ327 million ($A297.39 million) in the 12 months ending June 30 from $NZ263 million a year earlier and included a $NZ29 million loss on Air NZ's 26 per cent stake in Virgin Australia. 
Pretax normalised earnings were $US496 million, up 49 per cent on the previous year. The company said that was in line with its June guidance for pretax normalised earnings of between $NZ520 million and $NZ530 million, which was excluding losses from Virgin Australia. 
Operating revenue rose six per cent to $NZ4.93 billion with passenger sales growth of 6.8 per cent to $NZ4.1 billion. 
Mr Luxon says profitable growth had been at the heart of the company's restructuring over the past four years. 
"We've just had an investment grade rating last week. Of 300 commercial airlines in the world only 30 covered their cost of capital and only seven had an investment grade rating. Air New Zealand is among the top three airlines in the world," he said. 
Lower fuel prices added a $NZ120 million net benefit to the company during the financial year and Mr Luxon expects ongoing cheaper fuel prices to provide a $NZ300 million benefit in the year ahead under the airline's new hedging, although there will be some currency drag on that. 
The company has declared a fully imputed dividend of 9.5 cents per share, an increase of 73 per cent on the prior year. 
It will also pay a bonus of up to $NZ1400 to 8000 staff not on other incentive schemes on the back of the result. 
Air NZ is facing some headwinds ahead with its stranglehold on the domestic regional market set to end with Jetstar's expansion. 
The national carrier has said it won't be undercut on prices on regional routes and has cut lead-in fares by 11 to 40 per cent on most routes ahead of Jetstar's announcement in September of which regional destinations it will fly to from December. 
Mr Luxon said talk about the threatened domestic competition had been a "bit overblown". 
"It's not just Jetstar with its four aircraft, there are a lot of little airlines adding capacity. We have better aircraft at a lower cost and are not pressured on lower pricing," he said. 
There was good demand for the two new routes starting in December - Buenos Aires in Argentina and Houston in Texas - with the airline already considering adding capacity.
